**Chapter Sixty-Five**
Those of old who were adept in the Dao did not use it to enlighten the people but to make them simple. The people are difficult to govern because of their many wiles. Therefore, to govern the state with wiles is the state’s bane; to govern the state without wiles is the state’s blessing. To know these two is also a model. To know the model is called profound virtue. Profound virtue is deep, far-reaching—so deep it penetrates below, so far-reaching it encompasses all. It moves counter to things, yet attains great compliance.

---

**Chapter Sixty-Six**
The reason rivers and seas can be kings of the hundred valleys is that they are good at placing themselves below. Thus they can be kings of the hundred valleys. Therefore, if the sage wishes to be above the people, he must in his speech place himself below; if he wishes to lead the people, he must in his person place himself behind. Thus, though he dwells above, the people do not feel his weight; though he stands before, the people do not feel harmed. Therefore the world delights in exalting him and never tires of it. Because he does not contend, no one in the world can contend with him.

---

**Chapter Sixty-Seven**
All under heaven say that my Dao is great and seems to resemble nothing. Precisely because it is the Dao, it seems to resemble nothing. If it resembled anything, long before now it would have been small.

Now, that all under heaven say my Dao is great yet seems to resemble nothing—this is no cause for wonder. I possess three treasures, which I hold fast and cherish:

The first is called *compassion*—love for all things.
The second is called *frugality*—restraint and moderation.
The third is called *not daring to be first in the world*—refusing to contend with others.

Through compassion, one attains courage—for compassion is yielding, and yielding overcomes the rigid, thus it is courage.
Through frugality, one attains abundance—for frugality avoids waste, and without waste, one is ever sufficient, thus it is abundance.
Through not daring to be first in the world, one becomes the completion of all vessels and their leader—for *vessel* means form, and *leader* means ruler. Whatever achieves form, I call its ruler; thus it is the completion of all vessels and their leader.

Now, if one abandons compassion yet seeks courage,
abandons frugality yet seeks abundance,
abandons humility yet seeks precedence,
this is death.

For in battle, compassion brings victory;
in defense, it brings firmness.
Heaven will save such a one, guarding them with compassion.

Indeed, the reason the Dao is so great is that I possess three treasures, which I hold and cherish. The first is compassion; the second, frugality; the third, not daring to take precedence in the world. These three are what the people of the world do not value. What they value are courage, expansiveness, and bold advancement. Yet who knows that through compassion one attains courage, through frugality one attains abundance, and by not daring to take precedence one becomes the completion of all vessels and their leader? Now, if one abandons compassion and frugality, forsaking humility to pursue courage, abundance, and precedence, one will surely be resented by others—such a one is but a corpse awaiting death. For compassion as the Dao treats all things as parents love their children; though one may die for it, one does not refuse. Thus, in battle, it brings victory; in defense, it brings firmness. Heaven will save such a person, guarding them with compassion. If one is compassionate in all things, then all things will become one’s protectors.

**Chapter Sixty-Eight**
The skilled warrior is not martial;
The skilled fighter is not enraged;
The skilled conqueror does not contend;
The skilled employer of others places himself below them.
This is called the virtue of non-contention;
This is called employing the strength of others;
This is called matching Heaven—
The ultimate of antiquity.

---

**Chapter Sixty-Nine**
In the use of arms, there is a saying:
I dare not act as the host but prefer to be the guest;
I dare not advance an inch but would rather retreat a foot.
This is called advancing without advancing,
Repelling without arms,
Seizing without enemies,
Wielding without weapons.
There is no greater disaster than underestimating the enemy;
Underestimating the enemy nearly costs me my treasures.
Thus, when evenly matched armies meet,
The side that grieves will prevail.

---

**Chapter Seventy**
My words are very easy to know and very easy to practice,
Yet none in the world can know them or practice them.
Words have their lineage;
Affairs have their ruler.
It is only because of ignorance that they do not know me.
Those who know me are rare—
Thus I am esteemed.
Therefore, the sage wears coarse cloth while holding jade.

---

**Chapter Seventy-One**
To know yet to seem not to know is supreme;
Not to know yet to claim to know is a flaw.
Only by recognizing this flaw as a flaw
Can one avoid the flaw.
The sage is without flaw
Because he recognizes the flaw as a flaw—
Thus he is without flaw.

---

**Chapter Seventy-Two**
When the people do not fear authority,
Then great authority arrives.
Do not constrict their dwelling;
Do not stifle their livelihood.
Only by not stifling them
Will they not be stifled.
Therefore, the sage knows himself but does not display himself;
Loves himself but does not exalt himself.
Thus, he discards the latter and embraces the former.

**Chapter Seventy-Three**
To be brave in daring is to invite death;
To be brave in not daring is to live.
These two may bring either benefit or harm—
Yet what the Dao abhors,
Who knows the reason?
Thus even the sage finds it difficult.

The Dao of Heaven does not contend yet excels in victory;
Does not speak yet excels in response;
Is not summoned yet arrives of itself;
Is unhurried yet excels in planning.
The net of Heaven is vast and wide—
Though its mesh seems loose, nothing slips through.

**Chapter Seventy-Four**
If the people do not fear death,
How can death be used to frighten them?
If one could make the people always fear death,
Then those who act perversely—
Could I seize and kill them, who would dare resist?

Yet there is always One who presides over killing.
To kill in place of this One
Is like taking the place of a master carpenter to hew wood—
Few who do so avoid injuring their own hands.

**Chapter Seventy-Five**
The people’s hunger
Comes from their rulers’ excessive taxation—
Thus they starve.
The people’s unruliness
Comes from their rulers’ meddling—
Thus they are hard to govern.
The people’s disregard for death
Comes from their rulers’ lavish self-indulgence—
Thus they treat death lightly.
Only those who do not strive to preserve life
Are wiser than those who prize life.

**Chapter Seventy-Six**
When alive, humans are supple and weak;
When dead, stiff and strong.
When alive, plants are tender and fragile;
When dead, withered and dry.
Thus the stiff and strong are companions of death;
The supple and weak are companions of life.
Therefore, when weapons are strong, they do not prevail;
When trees are strong, they are felled.
The strong and great dwell below;
The supple and weak dwell above.

**Chapter Seventy-Two**
When the people do not fear authority,
Then great authority arrives.
Do not constrict their dwelling;
Do not stifle their livelihood.
Only by not stifling them
Will they not be stifled.
Therefore, the sage knows himself but does not display himself;
Loves himself but does not exalt himself.
Thus, he discards the latter and embraces the former.

chunks.original_text: 【老子之学主于尚柔故此章以人与草木之生死为喻言人之生也柔弱其死也坚强草木之生也柔脆其死也枯槁则凡有形者必以坚强而死柔弱而生一定之理也故用兵者恃强而骄必以取败而木之强也人伐之可见坚强之质粗而柔弱之用精也故知道者以强大为下柔弱为上】 第七十七章 天之道其犹张弓乎高者抑之下者举之【凡张弓者欲匀不欲偏故有高处则抑之有下处则举之】有余者损之不足者之【上二句言张弓此二句言天道】天之道损有余而不足人之道则不然损不足而奉有余【损不足之民奉有余之君】孰能以有余奉天下惟有道者【有道者法天道以为人道】是以圣人为而不恃成功而不居其不欲见贤耶【不欲见贤于人】 【此章言损上益下之道天道恶滛而好谦譬之张弓高者抑之下者举之故天道损有余以不足使之均平而已天道如此何至于人则不然而独损不足以奉有余也惟有道之人乃能损我之有余以奉天下故有为与成功皆我之所余而天下之所不足为之而不恃成功而不居天下享其赐而不知所以奉之者不已至乎而圣人仍不自见其贤凡以法天之道而已】 第七十八章 天下莫柔弱于水而攻坚强者莫之能先以其无以易之也【无以易之谓虽曲折万变而无易水之柔也】故柔之胜刚弱之胜强天下莫不知莫能行【人非不知而不肯行】是以圣人云受国之垢是谓社稷主【垢污秽也以比凶恶受之者纳之于柔道之中】受国之不祥是谓天下王【不祥妖孽也】正言若反【似反一世之常言其实正论】 【此亦言尚柔之用水为至柔而穿突陵谷无坚不攻天下之物莫能先之惟无以易其柔也故柔之胜刚弱之胜强如水之易见人莫不知而能柔能弱者之少则莫能行也故圣人有言曰受国之垢是谓社稷主受国之不祥是为天下王盖一国之内不能不善恶并出天下之大不能无妖孽杂生王者以柔道受之自然消归于尽犹之川泽之纳污耳夫垢与不祥世人之所恶也而谓王者受之此正言若反之妙也知道者其可忽诸】 第七十九章 和大怨必有余怨【怨者人之私隙和者强相和也】安可以为善【和怨非善道】是以圣人执左契而不责于人【契者刻木为劵中分之各执其一以表财物之信也契有左右左契在主财物之家待其右契而应之责者取之于人者也】故有德司契【司契者无心】无德司彻【彻强通之也】天道无亲常与善人【至虚惟天岂有所爱而亲之惟善人则与之耳】 【此言大道之无心也恩怨两忘方知至道人有大怨于我而必欲与之和虽无执怨之心犹知怨之为怨则余怨尚在安得谓之善道圣人为而不恃功成不居毎以有余奉天下如执左契以待人之自取此所以无怨而不责于人也故司契者自合其合吾无容心是为无德若必欲强通之则无德之司彻非有德之司契矣天道亦然天道无亲与常善人亦惟司契而已】 第八十章 小国寡民【国小民寡则俗自淳厚】使有什伯人之器而不用【器材器也其人之材堪为什夫伯夫之长者】使民重死而不远徙【重死则畏罪不远徙则安居】虽有舟车无所乘之【不致远以求利】虽有甲兵无所陈之【不恃力以求胜】使民结绳而用之【结防者上古之治也】甘其食美其服安其居乐其俗邻国相望鸡犬之音相闻【相望相闻言其近也】民至老死而不相往来【至老死言其乆也】 【此章盖老子叹文胜之而欲以大古之治救之也谓有道者得小国寡民而治之使之有才而不用重死而不远迁舟车甲兵置而弃之虽有书契亦无所施结防足矣以食所之食为甘以所服之服为美以所居之居为安充然自足乐其俗而不知其他即以邻国之相望鸡犬之相闻其近如此而老死不相往来盖各足而不相求也如是则淳淳闷闷所谓安平泰者非乎此老子因人心不古而思还醇反朴之俗欲复见之故有味乎言之也】
chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter Seventy-Seven**
The Dao of Heaven—
Is it not like the drawing of a bow?
What is high is pressed down;
What is low is lifted up.
What has excess is reduced;
What is deficient is supplemented.
The Dao of Heaven reduces excess
And supplements deficiency.
The way of humans is not so:
It reduces the deficient
To serve the excessive.
Who can take their excess
And offer it to the world?
Only those who possess the Dao.
Thus the sage acts without presuming,
Accomplishes without claiming credit—
Is it not that he does not wish to display his worth?

**Chapter Seventy-Eight**
Nothing in the world is softer or weaker than water,
Yet nothing surpasses it in attacking the hard and strong—
For there is nothing that can replace it.
Thus the weak overcomes the strong;
The soft overcomes the hard.
None in the world does not know this,
Yet none can practice it.
Therefore the sage says:
“One who bears the state’s disgrace
Is called the lord of the altars of soil and grain;
One who bears the state’s misfortunes
Is called the king of all under Heaven.”
True words seem contrary.

**Chapter Seventy-Nine**
When great resentment is reconciled,
Some resentment necessarily remains.
How can this be considered good?
Thus the sage holds the left tally
And does not demand from others.
Those with virtue oversee the tally;
Those without virtue oversee exactions.
The Dao of Heaven shows no partiality—
It always aligns with the good.

**Chapter Eighty**
Let the state be small, its people few.
Let there be tools enough for tens or hundreds,
Yet let them not be used.
Let the people regard death as weighty
And not wander far.
Though there be boats and carriages,
None will ride them;
Though there be armor and weapons,
None will display them.
Let the people return to knotting cords for records.
Let them savor their food,
Admire their clothing,
Feel at ease in their homes,
Delight in their customs.
Though neighboring states are within sight,
And the sounds of their dogs and chickens are heard,
The people will grow old and die
Without ever visiting one another.

chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter Eighty-One**

Truthful words are not fine;
Fine words are not truthful.
[Truthful words are those of substance; fine words are those of ornament.]
Good words are not contentious;
Contentious words are not good.
[Good words are those of purity; contentious words are those of display.]

The knowing are not broadly learned;
The broadly learned do not know.
[Knowing is to know the Dao; broad learning is to know many things.]

The sage does not accumulate.
[Empty as a valley.]
Having acted for others, they possess even more;
Having given to others, they have even greater abundance.
[They employ their abilities to act for others;
They extend what they have to give to others.]

The Dao of Heaven benefits and does not harm.
[To intentionally benefit things is to bring both harm and benefit;
The movement of Heaven is without intention—only its benefit is seen.]
The Dao of the sage acts and does not contend.
[Intentional action gives rise to contention;
Action without intention—where is there contention to be found?]

[The *Daodejing* takes non-contention as its central theme,
Thus, in concluding the text, it employs truthfulness to instruct people
and returns to the principle of non-contention.
Truthfulness can be relied upon and needs no embellishment—
hence, truthful words are not fine.
Fine words, however, are overly adorned and cannot be trusted.
Goodness accords with principle and needs no display—
hence, good words are not contentious.
Contentious words, however, are overly emphatic and cannot be good.
Knowing the constant is singular and needs no broad learning—
hence, the knowing are not broadly learned.
Those who are broadly learned, however, wander externally and may not know the Dao.
The Dao of the sage is to reject sagacity and discard knowledge,
emptied and open in all four directions—this is non-accumulation.
Yet in supplying the needs of the myriad things with perfect emptiness,
acting for others brings ever greater possession,
and giving to others brings ever greater abundance—
this is the marvel of emptiness that does not deplete and movement that ever arises.

For the sage shares the workings of Heaven.
The Dao of Heaven, though it possesses fine benefits, does not speak of them—
thus, only its benefit is seen, without harm.
The Dao of the sage acts without acting exhaustively
and never relies on what it possesses—
thus, it does not contend with things,
and none in the world can contend with it.
This is how the Dao of the sage aligns with Heaven
and why non-contention is its treasure.]
